Prornostics of the zueather indicated bg
birds and other animals A German writer,
whose work is noticed in the "Bulletin des
Sciences" says that BIRDS, ana some ami
mails. have foresight of the changes Of the
weather. The feathers Of birds are electri-
cal to high degree. and he ascribcs to this
their sensibility to change in the atmos-
phere. He gives the following indications,
among others.


Signs of far 7oeather.--NVhen swallows
ny very high, (because flies are then high in
the air;) ravens and hawks make more noise
than usual; wrens sing from 9 to 10 o'clock
A. M. and from to =. NJ. (their song af-
ter these hours announces rain;) glow worms
are stirring in the evening; insects and flies
sport in the air after sunset; bats show
themselves late; spiders weave their nets
quietly, and extend them much.


Signs of Rain-When ducks and geese
plunge into the water, shake themselves and
make a noise; swallows fly low; domestic
fowls, partridges and small birds sport in
the sand; cocks crow Immediately after sun
set; larks, sparrows, linnets and robbins
sing or make noise IN the mernings; pea
cocks and owls CRY louder and more frequent
than usual in the night; sheep and goats
skip about and quarrel; hogs play and scat
ter about their food; cats rub their head and
ears; dogs become restless, scratch the
ground, and growi in barking; foxes bark ;
frogs croak moro than usual; bats do not
leave their retreats III the evening; spiders
work but little, and make short threads /;
flies bite the legs of horses and cattle, and
fly about tumultuously; fish are disturbed.
SIGNS.

latin and Labor.-The following anec-
dote was related by the late John ADAMS,
even to the last of his life, with all that good
humour which was SO characteristic OF him,
and it is presumed has not yet passed from
the minds of many, who have heard 1t from
his own lips; few only Of his strong express
sions are remembered.


when was boy, had to study the Lat
IN grammar; but it was dull, and l hated 1t.
NV father was anxious to send me to Col
lege, and therefore l studied the grammar
till could bear with it no longer: and going
to my father / told him did not like study,
and asked for some other employment. II
was opposing his wishes, and he was quick
in his answer. We'll John, said he, if Latin
grammar does not suit you, you may try
ditching, perhaps that will my meadow
Wonder needs ditch, and you may put by
Latin and try that.


This seemed delightful change, and to
the meadow went. But soon found ditch
ing harder than Latin, and the first forenoon
was the longest I ever experienced. That
day ! ate the the bread OF labor, and glad
was Iwhen night came on. That night
made some comparison between Latir
grammer and ditchins. but said not wort
about it. I dug the next forenoon and want
ed to return to Latin at dinner, but It wa
humiliating. and could not do it. At nigh
toll conquered pride, and told my father
one OF the seycrcst trials Of my lite, that
he chose, I would go back to latin grammar
He was glad OF it; and if have since gaine'
any distinction, it has been owing to th
two days labor in that abomiuable ditch

Mr.. RDiron-In reply to your note on ny last
communication, can inform you that l was not
under any mistake respecting the eduction
valves Of the pump. have conversed with some
Of the members of the committee on the subject,
and have been informed by them that they had
unanimously agreed to have, what might per-
haps, be called guard vaiue. above the air ves-
sci in the main pipe, and this is the valve that
the committee have. on some occasions alluded
to, when they stated "there was no valve be-
tween the pump and reservoir at Fair Mount, I"

L1mentaJb. On Monday last, Sd inst whilst
some labourcrs were at work, cutting down a
high bank in this Borough, large quantity of
projecting earth fell and, instantly buried in its
ruins, Jaales Young, who was in the act of load
ing his cart. The cart was crushed to pieces,
and the nearest horse was so much injured as to
render him unfit for future service. The lifcless
body ofthc unfortunate man was dug out and
carried home to his parents.

DELAWARE ADVERTISER.
Thursday, Sept. 6, 1927.

at a sudden knock at your door you are
startled and alarmed at the. Interruption,
and for a second or two doubt whether you
are in your own study with classic in your
hand, or upon the plains of Lombardy, gaz-
ing at the hard and weather beaten counte-
nance of Hannibal. Read, if possible. SO in
tensely, that the morning shall have passed
away two hours before you imagine 1t was
finished, and let many night be given to
inquiry and meditation.


The great bar of improvement is what
may be called a languid st"dy; that indolent
and remitted occupation which requires no.
thing. and leaves us only disguised by a
fruitless effort. To profit by study we
should determine to possess; for it is like a
nettle; he who presses its surface lightly
only stings his fingers; to grasp it firmly, is
the only way to escape its mischief, and to
hold it safe.


A great deal has been said about the
question whether we should have stated
hours of study, or commit ourselves to occa-
sional appication-he who can be sure OF
his desire to apply at all times. may trust
himself to opportunities, but in general, 1t is
better to limit the irregular fancy of man.
This may be safe Recommendation, DO as
you please to do right The truth is, that
little hard thinking will overcome the
tendency of the mind to dissipation-by hard
thinking, mean determination to conhne
the fancy, and to this effect shake yourself,
try to rivet YOUR attention-ifit it flies off new
er mind, it will return-the images which
perpetually float before it become less ire
ouent, and you are finally absorbed in the
object of your study. The mind OF man is a
restive colt; all your effort is to keep IN
track, from which it is constantly flying off,

The first great step to the cultivation OF
the understanding is to get a habit OF study
I know that at first severe application is
painful thing; that, like the relish tor olives
and coffee it is only acquired by persever-
ance; but say perservere and you. acquire
it; nothing is tc be done without t;take your
Livy, work yourself SO into the lively events
which he places before you, that you see his
scenery, and become acquainted with ms

ucation Society states that the population OF

On the 9TH March, Brazilian squadron con-
sisting of four vessels Of war manned with 654
men, attacked the small establishment OF Pata-
gonas, but were repellcd with the loss OF three
of their vessels captured and the fourth got a.
ground and VENT pieces, and about 10 Of her
crew ipershed. of the vessels captured, one
mouated twenty guns, and the others three guns
each


Extract of letter from a Correspondent Of the


Witmingtonian, dated Buenos tyres, '1Prt1 ~


1927.


Mr.. Manuel Jose Gai cia, the ex-Secretary
of State, left here this morning in the British
packet for Rio, where he gees fully authorls-
ed and empowered to open negotiations OF
peace with the Brazilian Emperor. MIR. &. is
known to be the devoted tool Of the English,
who, under the pretext of mediating, are so
actively intriguing in this question for their
own final interest-and his appointment OH
this mission is, for them, first sreattriumph
in the progress Of their work. The basis OF
this epociation--dictated by Lord Ponsonby


is known with tolerable certainty to be
the fayorte project SO long cherished by the
English, viz: mutual evacuation OF the DIS
uuted territory, Banda Oriental, which is to
be erected into an independent Government
and Of which independence Great britain IS
to be the guardian. That Independence,
therefore, cannot be other than purely nom
ina,: because, by assuming the guaranty OF
it. England obtains there an indirect Intu-
ence of a character so powerful as will be
,antamount to actual sovereignty. 1t is even
e,id that three British Commissioners Will
be appointed to reside near, COUNSEL ana d.
r,ct the feeble and infant Government.
Numbers of British merchants have gone o.
yer from this place, and others have sent a
gents, with the object of making large pur-
chases Of land in that beautiful PROVINCE
now so clearly destined TO become mere
Colony Of Britain. Montevideo will be es-
,ablished free port; and the rival COM
merce of that place must bring Buenos Ay-
res and the Occidental country to compara-
tive ruin.


To the humiliating proposals which Mr.
Garcia is authorised to make, the Executive
now 6nds itself reduced by the disunited
state OF the Republic, throughout winch
civil war RACES, which assumes each day an
aspect more and more alarming The opPo'
sitlon party, dcnominated federalisfs, persist
in rejecting the Constitution, which eatao'
fishes the system of unity or consolidated
firm framed and sanctioned by the Genera
Conyress-and are clamourous for the Jede'
yal system. They have collected consid
cradle body of troops in the Interior whici
have obtained various successes over th'
forces sent against them by the general 60
v.rnmeut. Some Of the leading provinces
have actually declared war in q lorna
manner against the capital-are organizing
Federal Congress at the city OF San Juan
, in the Province of that name, where the.
invite all the Provinces to meet them' tor III
..--r -. S.l.-c 81. !.

About 10 o. slock, this phenomenon first
assumed a remarkable appearance. in the
torn of zone of white light, extending from
the f. n. Z. to the w. N. w. points of the
horizon; thongh diffused light, like the
break Of day had been observed in the Aor-
thern HORIZON during the previous half hour.
The zone or arch was midway between the
zenith and horizon. and about 100 broad, ex-
cept a. the western extremity, where it was
contracted nearly to point. Its Eastern cx-
tremity was faint, uniform, intermitting
light. about its middle, slender streaks or
columns became visible, converging towards
point far beyond the zenith, and moving
laterally from East to West. with the ra-
pidity of the lower stratum, of clouds in our
common Easterly storus. These columns
underlined as they approached the West.
where they appeared almost stationary
This appearance continued with little vara-
ton for three quarters of an hour. The
Eastern half Of the arch then disappeared
entirely, and the remaining part approach
ed the zenith in the form Of a slender, in
verted pyramid, and gave place to another
Of half the width, composed of broader col
unns, more distant, and well defined, NOV
ing but slowly, and presenting very s!nsu-
lar and striking appearance. "a supersti-
tious eye would have construed every col
umn into sword, portending some dire ca
lamity. The two semi. arches soon united,
the upper extremity disappeared. and the
lower part formed into three long, slender
columns, not unlike the tails of comets, very
we'll defined, overlapping each other, and
pointing south Of the zenith. These remain
cd permanent half all hour. and then grad
ually mingled into one, which soon vanished


At this time III, o'clock) the phenome-
non was restricted to the light in the North,
which had gradually becemc SO bright as to
cast faint shadow, and had assumed the
form of low rainbow, sending directly up
wards long, slender luminous beams. which
moved in a lateral direction, backward and
forward. and remained visible some minutes.
From this bow, more especially when the
columns faded, broad patches of light flash
ed upward, frequently from its whsle length.
These flashes were at times given oil in such
quick succession, as to present continued
{ undulating light. About IL o'clock, the
arch and columns were gradually resolved
into homogeneous light. which continued
TO send off flashes, and afterwards dlsap-
peared by degrees without Offering any
thing further worthy of notice.


The motion of the columns in the upper
: arch was ALWAYS from East to West. They
appeared very low in the atmosphere, and
one might readily have imagined them NOV
ed bv the wind. for when they first appear.
ed. an Eastcrly breeze sprang up, but soon
fell. and at the same tiae the motion OF the
y columns nearly ceased. But according te
the lowest calculations OF late writer's on the
. sub;ect. the Aurora Boreals does not ap'
proach nearer to tho Garth than 100 miles
. rs ~. admit this the columns moved at the
rate of more than three hundred miles in
minutc-as they passed through quad
rant Of a circle in about so seconds. The
light was mostly white, but had purpls


tinge where brightest.


The inverted pyramid bore some analogy
TO the zodiacal light. But it was not visible til


a hours after sunset, and its base was more
than 40 degrees from the ecliptic, though
the apex was nearly stationary in the place
Of the SUMS setting, Whereas the zediaca


light, is seen or an hour after sunset, gen.


erallv in the SUMS track, ard never without
the zodiac.


The evening of the 2sth was cool and ths


sky perfectly clear. The thermometer stooc
AZ zoo and the Barometer at 29.SO inches
A Northerly wind had prevailed for some
!, d.vs and on the 26th there had been vio
a len, Easterly storm.
!, In Cregory's Dict, article Aurora Boreal
is. is a description by Dalton, nearly answer
i, ing TO that Of the lower Bow. &c. but 1t


doubtful whether any account has been CIV
>, en- of phenomenon similar to that first de
;, scrib.d. The oldest inhabitants OF WI


minrt,n do not reeollect having seen it IL

A recontre took place this day in Ex-
change street, between Mr.. Goddard, a
gentleman of Boston, and Mr. Vance, of N.
York. in which the latter received very Sc
we're cowhding, in consequence OF his having
taken the unwarrantabe liberty Of publicly
posting Mr.. G. a fewdays since. 1t would APP
pear that Mr. Vance was not altogether unap'
prsed of the intention of his assallant, Tor
after the first blow was given, he presented
loaded pistol to the breast of Mr.. y. which
he fortunately parried, upon which Vance
drew a second, which Aashed in Mr.. G.''
face, but did not go off. Mr. Goddard al
the while applying the cowhidc. The by
standers then interfering, prevented further
mischief.

AS this is the season for making the best
condiment for fsh or steak that ever pantry
was furnished with. send the following re-
cipe:--


Take gallon of skinned tomatoes,


table spoonsful of salt,
4 do. do. black pepper, !


half a spoonful alspice,
8 pods red pepper.


table spoonsful of mustard.
Articles ground fine, and simmered slowly
in sharp vinegar, in pewter basin, three or
four hours, and then strained through wire
sieve and bottled close. 1t may be used in
two weeks. but improves much by age
Those who like the article may add. after
the simmering is over, and the ingredients
some what cooled. two table spoonsful OF the
juice of garlic. So much vinegar is to be
used as to have half gallon ofliquor when the
process is over Ton taste this is superior
to any West India ketchup that have ever
met with, and it is withal an excellent reme'
dy for dyspepsia'-.4mcr. Farmer.

A fact worthy of occupying the attention
g ro.trorologists this year is the co-exist-
.nce of a drought which threatens the crops
n mt the Northern countries OF Europe, and
inundatiens that lay waste the central and
Southern countries. 1t is apprehended that
n many provinces on the Baltic, the ex, :,
rene heat, Joined to the want of rain, wlll
dry the corn before it has attained IT'S full
rrowth, and it may happen that the SAINT! same
Countries will be ravaged by the Overlooking
ofthe rivers, which are swollen at their
sources. The height OF the Elbe in partlc-
ular gives rise to serious alarm.

Enfan Trouve.-rhc Philadelphia u
nted States Gazette says:--Yesterday at
scrneon, a we'll dressed female requested a
woman who was sitting in the High street
market, to hold her infant while she per
formed an errand at the distance of few
squares. The woman accordingly took the
child apparently about six months old. and
with it small bundle, containing the child's
clothes. The supposed mother. however,
did not redeem her pledge; and after wait
ing long time, the person who received the
child. was compelled to return to her own
house. with the gratuitous addition to her
family.

Road fran Buffalo 10 Washington.-Ar--
rangements are making to construct road
from Marlborough to Southport. in Pennsyl-
vania, on part of the route between the "a
bove places, by an incorporated company Of
that State. 1t is intended to make applica-
ton to Congress for assistance; and the
President of the Company, Mr.. Karthaus,
is expected to visit Buffalo. in the course Of
the present month, to obtain cooperation
in the design.

MONTREAL, August "a

Mr. Joseph r. Ladd. an enterprisng citi-
zen Of Alexandria, has met with serious
loss in the destruction of his new steam mill
by fire on Thursday morning. The mill
h a been in operation not more than fort
night, and was not insured. The loss we
understand is estimated at about sixteen
tn nsand dollars. The fire, which it is be-
lievcd was accidental. was discovered by the
watchmcn about three O'Clock in the morn
ing.

full articles.headline: SIGNS.
full articles.article:
Prornostics of the zueather indicated bg
birds and other animals A German writer,
whose work is noticed in the "Bulletin des
Sciences" says that BIRDS, ana some ami
mails. have foresight of the changes Of the
weather. The feathers Of birds are electri-
cal to high degree. and he ascribcs to this
their sensibility to change in the atmos-
phere. He gives the following indications,
among others.


Signs of far 7oeather.--NVhen swallows
ny very high, (because flies are then high in
the air;) ravens and hawks make more noise
than usual; wrens sing from 9 to 10 o'clock
A. M. and from to =. NJ. (their song af-
ter these hours announces rain;) glow worms
are stirring in the evening; insects and flies
sport in the air after sunset; bats show
themselves late; spiders weave their nets
quietly, and extend them much.


Signs of Rain-When ducks and geese
plunge into the water, shake themselves and
make a noise; swallows fly low; domestic
fowls, partridges and small birds sport in
the sand; cocks crow Immediately after sun
set; larks, sparrows, linnets and robbins
sing or make noise IN the mernings; pea
cocks and owls CRY louder and more frequent
than usual in the night; sheep and goats
skip about and quarrel; hogs play and scat
ter about their food; cats rub their head and
ears; dogs become restless, scratch the
ground, and growi in barking; foxes bark ;
frogs croak moro than usual; bats do not
leave their retreats III the evening; spiders
work but little, and make short threads /;
flies bite the legs of horses and cattle, and
fly about tumultuously; fish are disturbed.

latin and Labor.-The following anec-
dote was related by the late John ADAMS,
even to the last of his life, with all that good
humour which was SO characteristic OF him,
and it is presumed has not yet passed from
the minds of many, who have heard 1t from
his own lips; few only Of his strong express
sions are remembered.


when was boy, had to study the Lat
IN grammar; but it was dull, and l hated 1t.
NV father was anxious to send me to Col
lege, and therefore l studied the grammar
till could bear with it no longer: and going
to my father / told him did not like study,
and asked for some other employment. II
was opposing his wishes, and he was quick
in his answer. We'll John, said he, if Latin
grammar does not suit you, you may try
ditching, perhaps that will my meadow
Wonder needs ditch, and you may put by
Latin and try that.


This seemed delightful change, and to
the meadow went. But soon found ditch
ing harder than Latin, and the first forenoon
was the longest I ever experienced. That
day ! ate the the bread OF labor, and glad
was Iwhen night came on. That night
made some comparison between Latir
grammer and ditchins. but said not wort
about it. I dug the next forenoon and want
ed to return to Latin at dinner, but It wa
humiliating. and could not do it. At nigh
toll conquered pride, and told my father
one OF the seycrcst trials Of my lite, that
he chose, I would go back to latin grammar
He was glad OF it; and if have since gaine'
any distinction, it has been owing to th
two days labor in that abomiuable ditch

full articles.headline: Library Election.
full articles.article:
At an Election for officers of the VII.

day last, at the Town Hall, the following

ISAAC II. STARR,

JOHN BULLOCK,


SAM'L HILLES,


GEN. JOHN CALDWELL,


r. A. HENDERSON,


JACOB ALRICHS,


HENRY HEAD.

Of the members of the committee on the subject,
and have been informed by them that they had
unanimously agreed to have, what might per-
haps, be called guard vaiue. above the air ves-
sci in the main pipe, and this is the valve that

full articles.headline:
TEzE WIzr1xrJ GTOMIAM,

DELAWARE ADVERTISER.

Thursday, Sept. 6, 1927.
full articles.article:
L1mentaJb. On Monday last, Sd inst whilst
some labourcrs were at work, cutting down a
high bank in this Borough, large quantity of
projecting earth fell and, instantly buried in its
ruins, Jaales Young, who was in the act of load
ing his cart. The cart was crushed to pieces,
and the nearest horse was so much injured as to
render him unfit for future service. The lifcless
body ofthc unfortunate man was dug out and
carried home to his parents.

at a sudden knock at your door you are
startled and alarmed at the. Interruption,
and for a second or two doubt whether you
are in your own study with classic in your
hand, or upon the plains of Lombardy, gaz-
ing at the hard and weather beaten counte-
nance of Hannibal. Read, if possible. SO in
tensely, that the morning shall have passed
away two hours before you imagine 1t was
finished, and let many night be given to
inquiry and meditation.


The great bar of improvement is what
may be called a languid st"dy; that indolent
and remitted occupation which requires no.
thing. and leaves us only disguised by a
fruitless effort. To profit by study we
should determine to possess; for it is like a
nettle; he who presses its surface lightly
only stings his fingers; to grasp it firmly, is
the only way to escape its mischief, and to
hold it safe.


A great deal has been said about the
question whether we should have stated
hours of study, or commit ourselves to occa-
sional appication-he who can be sure OF
his desire to apply at all times. may trust
himself to opportunities, but in general, 1t is
better to limit the irregular fancy of man.
This may be safe Recommendation, DO as
you please to do right The truth is, that
little hard thinking will overcome the
tendency of the mind to dissipation-by hard
thinking, mean determination to conhne
the fancy, and to this effect shake yourself,
try to rivet YOUR attention-ifit it flies off new
er mind, it will return-the images which
perpetually float before it become less ire
ouent, and you are finally absorbed in the
object of your study. The mind OF man is a
restive colt; all your effort is to keep IN
track, from which it is constantly flying off,

full articles.headline: READING.
full articles.article:
The first great step to the cultivation OF
the understanding is to get a habit OF study
I know that at first severe application is
painful thing; that, like the relish tor olives
and coffee it is only acquired by persever-
ance; but say perservere and you. acquire
it; nothing is tc be done without t;take your
Livy, work yourself SO into the lively events
which he places before you, that you see his
scenery, and become acquainted with ms

full articles.article:
We are pleased to see the Red Rover; by
Coopcr announced as being already in the
press. 1t is Sea Story, much may consc-
ouently be expected. for as soon as this wri-
ter gets upon the ocean he is perfectly at
home.


1t is said that the gold gathered from
the sweepings of one Jewellers shop At
Philadelphia, amounts to 1900 dollars
wear. This is a triAe compared with the re-
corded waste Of gold in India, by the friction
of ornaments.
The greatest insult that can be conceived,
is after conquering country, and killing
the women and children, to offer the few
surviving men leave to return honieH
The report of the death of Mr., WM OAR
nv georrapher, is unfounded. He is in good
health. as a letter from HIM assures the cdi-
tors of the Democratic Press.
In the British House of Commons. on the
2sth of June, DIR. Lush..ston gave notice Of
motion relstveto the British "Brazilian
Mining Company" which he understood
'employed 700 slaves, and were about to
purchase 700 more"


The London New Times announces that
Sir James M'Intosh is Immediately going to
press with his History Of Engfand," Sir
James was supposed to have abandoned this
enterprise; we reJolCe tndt II 10 W oS cheSue-
ed by so able writer.


Mrs. Mary Covert of Owego, n. Y. aged
81 wears, drowned herself and her infant
aged two weeks, on the 9th ult. in fit OF in
sanity, it is supposed-leaving husband
and four children.


Female Industry.-Sally Johnson. Of Sem
pronins: Cayuga CO. spun l70 knots Of WOOL
len warn. OH a common wheel, by day light.
Miss Emeline Gale, of Bennington. Gennes-
see county-140 knots.


A conyterfeiter by the name OF Wallace
has been convicted at Pittsburg, and SEN
fenced to three years confinement in the
! Penitentiary.


Two men near Red River, La. lately drank
gallon of whskey upon bet, in the space
of few minutes. The person who proposed
the bet, went for more, but on his return
found the others lifeless.


Mr.. Henry Darling, attached to the COM
many of Eouestrians now in the city of Lam
easter. was engaged on Thursday afternoon,
with Others in coursing horses in an orch
ard. and in some manner chow we have not
heard his head came in contact with one
of the trees, by which he was instantly kill
ed.


As soon as the election of Gen. Lafayette
was known at Marselles, the Americans III
that town illuminated their hotels. The n
merican vessels in tho harbor also hoisted
their colors in testimony of rejoicing upon
the occasion.


Jerome Napoleon Buonaparte came passenger
in the William Byrne, arrived at New-York.
Our booksellers advertise the "Epicurian," {
tale by Thomas Moore. The extracts from the
work, which have been offered to the public
promise one of the richest treats that the gen
ius ofthat pleasing writer has ever afforded.

brought 1872 Saxony Sheep.

indentured apprentice, named MAHLON LU.
KENS, 16 years old, about five feet high, pale

cents, but no charges.


THOMAS A. STERRETT,

full articles.headline: AMrnIcAN CONVENTION.
full articles.article:
The twentieth biennial stated meeting OF the
.,merican Convention for Promoting the Aboli-
lion Of Slavery &c. will be held at Philadelphia,
on Sd day Tuesday, the I'd day of 10th month,
(october) next, at 10 o'clock, A. NJ to which
the Abolition and Manumisson Societies, not
heretofore represented arc invited to send Dele
gates.


Phiiadelghia, 4th mo. 81, 1927


N. Il. Printers of Newspapers throughout
the Union, are respectfully requested to give
the above notice few insertions.


Extract from the Constitution ofthe Convention


"Article ID. The Convention shall be com,
posed of such representatives as the respective
Societies associated to protect the rights OF free
persons of color, or to promote tic Abolition OF
Slavery. within the United States, may think
proper to Provided that the number
from any one Society shall not exceed ten"

of Shakers, containing 81 persons, in Entielos
Conn. by throwing into the pump wei, guam
tity of Arsenic. One person only suffered Sc,
verely. There was enough arsenic dePositeo
to kill thousand persons. ,


According to the report Of NJ. M. Peiletier ana
Caventou, to the French Academy OF Medicine,
10000 ounces ofsulphate Of quinine, was manu-
featured in 1926, in France.


Mr. j. Bird sal, of Sing Sing, killed rat
tie snake last week. Just before ne came
up to the snake, he saw several snakes max
ing down the throat Of the mother. On
opening the snake, thirty three young snakes
were found, each ten inches long.


A new Quarterly Review Of Foreign Lit
erature and Science is about to be establish
ed in Londen.


An exceeding drought prevails in Seor-
gia. Whole cornhelds are entirely destroy
ed. ii


The Annual Report of the American Ed
ucation Society states that the population OF
the United States is advanced at the rate OF
1000 every day-365 900 year.


At bear hunt in Pitt6eld, VT, few days
ago, at which upwards of10o persons were
engaged, four bears were killed and one cub
taken alive.

full articles.headline: IMPORTANT FROM BUENos AYREs.
full articles.article:
We hayr received from our Correspondent at
Buenos Ayres, files OF the "American" and
"Britsh Packet" up to the 2lst April, from
which extracts shall be given next week.


On the 9TH March, Brazilian squadron con-
sisting of four vessels Of war manned with 654
men, attacked the small establishment OF Pata-
gonas, but were repellcd with the loss OF three
of their vessels captured and the fourth got a.
ground and VENT pieces, and about 10 Of her
crew ipershed. of the vessels captured, one
mouated twenty guns, and the others three guns
each


Extract of letter from a Correspondent Of the


Witmingtonian, dated Buenos tyres, '1Prt1 ~


1927.


Mr.. Manuel Jose Gai cia, the ex-Secretary
of State, left here this morning in the British
packet for Rio, where he gees fully authorls-
ed and empowered to open negotiations OF
peace with the Brazilian Emperor. MIR. &. is
known to be the devoted tool Of the English,
who, under the pretext of mediating, are so
actively intriguing in this question for their
own final interest-and his appointment OH
this mission is, for them, first sreattriumph
in the progress Of their work. The basis OF
this epociation--dictated by Lord Ponsonby


is known with tolerable certainty to be
the fayorte project SO long cherished by the
English, viz: mutual evacuation OF the DIS
uuted territory, Banda Oriental, which is to
be erected into an independent Government
and Of which independence Great britain IS
to be the guardian. That Independence,
therefore, cannot be other than purely nom
ina,: because, by assuming the guaranty OF
it. England obtains there an indirect Intu-
ence of a character so powerful as will be
,antamount to actual sovereignty. 1t is even
e,id that three British Commissioners Will
be appointed to reside near, COUNSEL ana d.
r,ct the feeble and infant Government.
Numbers of British merchants have gone o.
yer from this place, and others have sent a
gents, with the object of making large pur-
chases Of land in that beautiful PROVINCE
now so clearly destined TO become mere
Colony Of Britain. Montevideo will be es-
,ablished free port; and the rival COM
merce of that place must bring Buenos Ay-
res and the Occidental country to compara-
tive ruin.


To the humiliating proposals which Mr.
Garcia is authorised to make, the Executive
now 6nds itself reduced by the disunited
state OF the Republic, throughout winch
civil war RACES, which assumes each day an
aspect more and more alarming The opPo'
sitlon party, dcnominated federalisfs, persist
in rejecting the Constitution, which eatao'
fishes the system of unity or consolidated
firm framed and sanctioned by the Genera
Conyress-and are clamourous for the Jede'
yal system. They have collected consid
cradle body of troops in the Interior whici
have obtained various successes over th'
forces sent against them by the general 60
v.rnmeut. Some Of the leading provinces
have actually declared war in q lorna
manner against the capital-are organizing
Federal Congress at the city OF San Juan
, in the Province of that name, where the.
invite all the Provinces to meet them' tor III
..--r -. S.l.-c 81. !.

A 60ring match was advertised short time
since at Lyons, and about 1000 persons met
buta discussion having arisen between the COM
batants, the public took part, and general set
to followed. 1t is thought that this will satisfy
the citizens of of Lyons.

full articles.headline: ICoMMUNIcATED.1
full articles.article:
the 28th August, 1897; by HESRr GIBBoys.-


Iiead bctoye the DeLlWare .icademy Of Natural


Science, Sept. 1st, 1927.


About 10 o. slock, this phenomenon first
assumed a remarkable appearance. in the
torn of zone of white light, extending from
the f. n. Z. to the w. N. w. points of the
horizon; thongh diffused light, like the
break Of day had been observed in the Aor-
thern HORIZON during the previous half hour.
The zone or arch was midway between the
zenith and horizon. and about 100 broad, ex-
cept a. the western extremity, where it was
contracted nearly to point. Its Eastern cx-
tremity was faint, uniform, intermitting
light. about its middle, slender streaks or
columns became visible, converging towards
point far beyond the zenith, and moving
laterally from East to West. with the ra-
pidity of the lower stratum, of clouds in our
common Easterly storus. These columns
underlined as they approached the West.
where they appeared almost stationary
This appearance continued with little vara-
ton for three quarters of an hour. The
Eastern half Of the arch then disappeared
entirely, and the remaining part approach
ed the zenith in the form Of a slender, in
verted pyramid, and gave place to another
Of half the width, composed of broader col
unns, more distant, and well defined, NOV
ing but slowly, and presenting very s!nsu-
lar and striking appearance. "a supersti-
tious eye would have construed every col
umn into sword, portending some dire ca
lamity. The two semi. arches soon united,
the upper extremity disappeared. and the
lower part formed into three long, slender
columns, not unlike the tails of comets, very
we'll defined, overlapping each other, and
pointing south Of the zenith. These remain
cd permanent half all hour. and then grad
ually mingled into one, which soon vanished


At this time III, o'clock) the phenome-
non was restricted to the light in the North,
which had gradually becemc SO bright as to
cast faint shadow, and had assumed the
form of low rainbow, sending directly up
wards long, slender luminous beams. which
moved in a lateral direction, backward and
forward. and remained visible some minutes.
From this bow, more especially when the
columns faded, broad patches of light flash
ed upward, frequently from its whsle length.
These flashes were at times given oil in such
quick succession, as to present continued
{ undulating light. About IL o'clock, the
arch and columns were gradually resolved
into homogeneous light. which continued
TO send off flashes, and afterwards dlsap-
peared by degrees without Offering any
thing further worthy of notice.


The motion of the columns in the upper
: arch was ALWAYS from East to West. They
appeared very low in the atmosphere, and
one might readily have imagined them NOV
ed bv the wind. for when they first appear.
ed. an Eastcrly breeze sprang up, but soon
fell. and at the same tiae the motion OF the
y columns nearly ceased. But according te
the lowest calculations OF late writer's on the
. sub;ect. the Aurora Boreals does not ap'
proach nearer to tho Garth than 100 miles
. rs ~. admit this the columns moved at the
rate of more than three hundred miles in
minutc-as they passed through quad
rant Of a circle in about so seconds. The
light was mostly white, but had purpls


tinge where brightest.


The inverted pyramid bore some analogy
TO the zodiacal light. But it was not visible til


a hours after sunset, and its base was more
than 40 degrees from the ecliptic, though
the apex was nearly stationary in the place
Of the SUMS setting, Whereas the zediaca


light, is seen or an hour after sunset, gen.


erallv in the SUMS track, ard never without
the zodiac.


The evening of the 2sth was cool and ths


sky perfectly clear. The thermometer stooc
AZ zoo and the Barometer at 29.SO inches
A Northerly wind had prevailed for some
!, d.vs and on the 26th there had been vio
a len, Easterly storm.
!, In Cregory's Dict, article Aurora Boreal
is. is a description by Dalton, nearly answer
i, ing TO that Of the lower Bow. &c. but 1t


doubtful whether any account has been CIV
>, en- of phenomenon similar to that first de
;, scrib.d. The oldest inhabitants OF WI


minrt,n do not reeollect having seen it IL

EDWIN p. ATLEE, Secretary

View York, tug. IS.
PIIRIIC CAS'rIGAIION.
full articles.article:
A recontre took place this day in Ex-
change street, between Mr.. Goddard, a
gentleman of Boston, and Mr. Vance, of N.
York. in which the latter received very Sc
we're cowhding, in consequence OF his having
taken the unwarrantabe liberty Of publicly
posting Mr.. G. a fewdays since. 1t would APP
pear that Mr. Vance was not altogether unap'
prsed of the intention of his assallant, Tor
after the first blow was given, he presented
loaded pistol to the breast of Mr.. y. which
he fortunately parried, upon which Vance
drew a second, which Aashed in Mr.. G.''
face, but did not go off. Mr. Goddard al
the while applying the cowhidc. The by
standers then interfering, prevented further
mischief.

full articles.headline: FOR TOMATTO CATSUP-haya gal
full articles.article:
LOH.


AS this is the season for making the best
condiment for fsh or steak that ever pantry
was furnished with. send the following re-
cipe:--


Take gallon of skinned tomatoes,


table spoonsful of salt,
4 do. do. black pepper, !


half a spoonful alspice,
8 pods red pepper.


table spoonsful of mustard.
Articles ground fine, and simmered slowly
in sharp vinegar, in pewter basin, three or
four hours, and then strained through wire
sieve and bottled close. 1t may be used in
two weeks. but improves much by age
Those who like the article may add. after
the simmering is over, and the ingredients
some what cooled. two table spoonsful OF the
juice of garlic. So much vinegar is to be
used as to have half gallon ofliquor when the
process is over Ton taste this is superior
to any West India ketchup that have ever
met with, and it is withal an excellent reme'
dy for dyspepsia'-.4mcr. Farmer.

A fact worthy of occupying the attention
g ro.trorologists this year is the co-exist-
.nce of a drought which threatens the crops
n mt the Northern countries OF Europe, and
inundatiens that lay waste the central and
Southern countries. 1t is apprehended that
n many provinces on the Baltic, the ex, :,
rene heat, Joined to the want of rain, wlll
dry the corn before it has attained IT'S full
rrowth, and it may happen that the SAINT! same
Countries will be ravaged by the Overlooking
ofthe rivers, which are swollen at their
sources. The height OF the Elbe in partlc-
ular gives rise to serious alarm.

Enfan Trouve.-rhc Philadelphia u
nted States Gazette says:--Yesterday at
scrneon, a we'll dressed female requested a
woman who was sitting in the High street
market, to hold her infant while she per
formed an errand at the distance of few
squares. The woman accordingly took the
child apparently about six months old. and
with it small bundle, containing the child's
clothes. The supposed mother. however,
did not redeem her pledge; and after wait
ing long time, the person who received the
child. was compelled to return to her own
house. with the gratuitous addition to her
family.

Road fran Buffalo 10 Washington.-Ar--
rangements are making to construct road
from Marlborough to Southport. in Pennsyl-
vania, on part of the route between the "a
bove places, by an incorporated company Of
that State. 1t is intended to make applica-
ton to Congress for assistance; and the
President of the Company, Mr.. Karthaus,
is expected to visit Buffalo. in the course Of
the present month, to obtain cooperation
in the design.

Mr. Joseph r. Ladd. an enterprisng citi-
zen Of Alexandria, has met with serious
loss in the destruction of his new steam mill
by fire on Thursday morning. The mill
h a been in operation not more than fort
night, and was not insured. The loss we
understand is estimated at about sixteen
tn nsand dollars. The fire, which it is be-
lievcd was accidental. was discovered by the
watchmcn about three O'Clock in the morn
ing.
